Pillars of Eternity
Prepare to be enchanted by a world where the choices you make and the paths you choose shape your destiny. Obsidian Entertainment, the developer of Fallout: New Vegas™ and South Park: The Stick of Truth™, together with Paradox Interactive is proud to present Pillars of Eternity.
User reviews: Very Positive (5,639 reviews) - 89% of the 5,639 user reviews for this game are positive.
Release Date: Mar 26, 2015

Recent updates View all (29)

October 26

Patch Beta for Update 2.03 is Now Live and Short Stories!

Hey, all!

Today we are excited to announce that the first of four new short stories in the world of Pillars of Eternity has been released. First up is a story following the companion, Sagani, written by Pillars of Eternity narrative designer, Carrie Patel! You can access the story, entitled "The Ratcatcher," here:

https://eternity.obsidian.net/media/stories

We are also happy to announce that the Patch Beta for Update 2.03 is now live on Steam.

You can get instructions on how to access the Patch Beta here:

http://forums.obsidian.net/topic/76849-patch-betas-on-steam

The following is the work in progress patch notes for the Update 2.03:

Steam Controller:

- Pillars of Eternity now has support for the Steam controller. The default template will be set once the update is live.
- There is a suggested configuration that can be found on the templates that are accessed in Steam's big screen mode.
- New key bindings have been added to support additional actions needed for the Steam controller control schemes.

Fighter Changes:

- Base Deflection raised up by 5.
- Knockdown gets a 1.20 damage multiplier (no longer gets bonus Crush damage)
- Disciplined Barrage raised from +10 to +15 Accuracy
- Armored Grace has been scaled from -15% to -20% Armor Recovery Penalty
- Clear Out base Crush damage increased from 10-16 to 15-22. Scales every 3 levels after 7 by 15%.
- Into the Fray's damage scales every 3 levels after 5 by 15%.

Major Fixes:

- Fixed an issue that was causing certain quests to take experience instead of granting it.
- Fixed a problem with chanters not being able to set their chants properly after they have retrained.
- Fixed an issue where retraining was allowing characters to obtain unlimited skill points.
- Using store filters now only shows the appropriate items instead of graying out other items in the store panel.
- Fixed multiple issues with the stronghold and how it interacted with DLC content.
- Fixed an issue that caused the main character to lose his or her background shortly after character creation.

Party/Companion AI:

- Can now enable/disable AI on multiple non-pet characters at the same time.
- Fixed issues where AI would not automatically attack enemies.
- Fixed issues where AI would engage enemies that were hidden by fog of war.
- Fixed an issue where AI casters would cast per-rest abilities despite the option being turned off.
- Fixed an issue that caused AI controlled party members to attack other party members that were charmed or confused.
- Reviewed and updated what spells/abilities are cast in AI profiles for multiple classes.

Monsters/Enemies/NPCs:

- Multiple enemy types have been given immunities to certain afflictions.
- These enemy types have had their bestiary updated to reflect these immunities.
- Fixed multiple issues regarding NPC reactivity after completing certain quests
- Fixed multiple bugs regarding Enemies/NPCs detecting stealthed characters and how they react to stealthed characters that they detect.
- Rebalanced requirements for full bestiary unlocks for certain enemies that were not unlocking on easy difficulty.
- Added additional bestiary information for multiple enemy types.

Abilities/Talents:

- Minor Grimoire Imprint has had multiple fixes and now works as intended.
- Fixed an issue with the Ranger's Stalker's Link ability adding too much accuracy in some situations.
- Fixed an issue that caused certain buffs and abilities to persist after combat ended.
- St. Ydwen's Redeemer's Revive the Fallen ability now works correctly.
- Fixed an issue that allowed Chanters to choose an extra talent.
- Fixed an issue where the debuff "Bonded Grief" would not be removed after reviving animal companions.

Quests:

- Fixed an issue with The Siege of Cragholdt that kept the quest from progressing.
- Fixed an issue with the Grey Sleeper questline that would cause it fail after completing it.
- Fixed multiple issues with the "Sacrificial Bloodlines" quest.
- Fixed an issue that would break game progression after talking to Maerwald.
- Fixed an issue that didn't allow the player to complete the game after killing Thaos.

Achievement:
- Fixed an issue with the Herald of the Old Flame achievement being awarded prematurely.
- Fixed an issue that kept players from receiving White March Part 1 achievements.

Items:
- Fixed an issue that caused enchants to be removed when a character retrained.
- Fixed an issue that allowed Sentinel's Girdle to be equipped in a ring slot.
- Fixed enchantment issues with Badgradr's Barricade.
- Fixed an issue where the draining modification on weapons would disappear.
- Fixed an issue that caused Sabra Marie to be mis-categorized.

Localization:

- Fixed multiple issues with Korean text.

Reviews

“Obsidian (and its Kickstarter backers) have done it: Pillars of Eternity is one of the best RPGs since Baldur's Gate.”
9/10 – IGN

“It's the best new, isometric RPG to come out in years”
5/5 – The Escapist

“This is a big, fat, deep adventure that lets you carve your own unique path through a fantasy world that’s been brilliantly brought to life with rich, evocative writing. It’s a game steeped in a bygone era of computer RPG design, but somehow it doesn’t feel archaic. Obsidian have always been bound to other peoples’ worlds—Fallout, Dungeons & Dragons, Star Wars, South Park—but in creating their own from scratch, they’ve made not only their best game to date, but one of the best RPGs on PC.”
92/100 – PC Gamer

Champion Edition



Pillars of Eternity Champion Edition:

Digital Original Soundtrack:
This soundtrack contains many of the game's music tracks performed by a live orchestra. Contains at least 17 tracks in MP3 and FLAC formats.

Digital Campaign Almanac:
The Campaign Almanac contains everything related to the lore, history, and world of Eora as originally told by Hylsman Horag and revised by the Hand Occult. The 35 page almanac has commentary provided by a variety of authors and is an engrossing read for anyone keen to delve deeper into the world of the Pillars of Eternity.

Making of Documentary:
A video documentary of the entire Pillars of Eternity development process - from beginning to end. Includes commentary from the developers and behind the scenes footage of game shows and events.

Digital Hi-res Game Map:
A high resolution map of Eora's Eastern Reach. Details include locations that players will be traveling to and locations that they may be seen in future Pillars of Eternity products.

Wallpapers:
High resolution and multi-monitor wallpapers of cool concept art and in-game artwork.

Ringtones:
Short clips of sounds and music from Pillars of Eternity. Perfect as mobile ringtones.

Royal Edition



Pillars of Eternity Royal Edition:

Digital Novella by Chris Avellone:
A digital novella that focus on the backstory of some of the more interesting characters that players may encounter over the course of their travels in Pillars of Eternity.

Collector’s Book PDF:
Digital version of the book that is being published by Dark Horse. It contains lots of information and art on the setting, story, and creatures of Pillars of Eternity. 112 pages.

Hi-res Concept Art pieces:
High resolution pieces of our concept art. Contains everything from concepts of areas and creatures to props and mood pieces.

Digital Strategy Guide:
Digital version of our strategy guide from Prima penned by the same writer of the Fallout: New Vegas guide. Contains all the information players will need to master Pillars of Eternity and reveal all of the content available.

Digital Original Soundtrack:
This soundtrack contains many of the game's music tracks performed by a live orchestra.Contains at least 17 tracks in MP3 and FLAC formats

Digital Campaign Almanac:
The Campaign Almanac contains everything related to the lore, history, and world of Eora as originally told by Hylsman Horag and revised by the Hand Occult. The 35 page almanac has commentary provided by a variety of authors and is an engrossing read for anyone keen to delve deeper into the world of the Pillars of Eternity.

Making of Documentary:
A video documentary of the entire Pillars of Eternity development process - from beginning to end. Includes commentary from the developers and behind the scenes footage of game shows and events.

Digital Hi-res Game Map:
A high resolution map of Eora's Eastern Reach. Details include locations that players will be traveling to and locations that they may be seen in future Pillars of Eternity products.

Wallpapers:
High resolution and multi-monitor wallpapers of cool concept art and in-game artwork.

Ringtones:
Short clips of sounds and music from Pillars of Eternity. Perfect as mobile ringtones.

About This Game

Pillars of Eternity:
Prepare to be enchanted by a world where the choices you make and the paths you choose shape your destiny. Obsidian Entertainment, the developer of Fallout: New Vegas™ and South Park: The Stick of Truth™, together with Paradox Interactive is proud to present Pillars of Eternity.

Recapture the deep sense of exploration, the joy of a pulsating adventure, and the thrill of leading your own band of companions across a new fantasy realm and into the depths of monster-infested dungeons in search of lost treasures and ancient mysteries.

So gather your party, venture forth, and embrace adventure as you delve into a realm of wonder, nostalgia, and the excitement of classic RPGs with Obsidian’s Pillars of Eternity!

Main features:
  • Play as any one of six races: Human, Aumaua, Dwarf, Elf, Godlike and Orlan.
  • Utilize five core skills to overcome any situation: Stealth, Athletics, Lore, Mechanics and Survival.
  • Deep character customization: Build a character as one of eleven classes such as Barbarian, Chanter, Cipher, Druid, Fighter, Monk, Paladin, Priest, Ranger, Rogue and Wizard.
  • Sculpt your own story: Side with various factions using a reputation system, where your actions and choices have far reaching consequences.
  • Explore a rich and diverse world: Beautiful pre-rendered environments laced with an engaging story and characters bring the world to life.
READ MORE

321 of 376 people (85%) found this review helpful
7
Mr. Nekator
2,934 products in account
63 reviews
Recommended
47.4 hrs on record
Posted: May 31
Pillars of Eternity, one more try to make the "sucessor of Baldurs Gate", one of the biggest Kickstarter projects made by rpg veterans Obsidian Entertainment.

So, after nearly 50 hours playtime (i´m around the last third of the game) what can i say to the big promises?
First off, the world of PoE is very detailed for a newly made one, the history, races and classes are partly innovative, partly good old fantasy genre like.

The gameplay itself naturally orientates itself on the old masters, you create your character, who can alter the fate of the world in an epic storyline, while finding allies for his group on the way through the story (which can alternatively be filled with custom made characters.. or you can even try to go through it alone).
Regarding classes there are new ones like the cipher and many known ones from barbarian to priests to the different gods (a nice extra for these is, that the way how they act throughout the game influences how "satisfied" their deity is with them).

Regarding classes and "improvements" here also shows one of the main changes of PoE, there are rather less skills, then usually known in old time rpgs. Also the classes are not limited as how they advance in them. For me, i honestly preferred the old way a bit, when not everyone could learn anything but to each his own. Also it seems to me that especially the rogue class suffers from that choice, as everyone can learn about traps etc. now.. so the only thing really special about them is backstabbing. Stealing isn´t possible anyways.
When advancing in levels the classes differentiate again a bit more through perks, which can be aquired on selected levels (some general, some bound to different requirements).

Graphic and music are top level for this kind of game, only the camera possibilities/movements could be improved, especially during battles or while in towns etc.

Regarding quests, dialogue and story in general there are few things to complain about, the main storyline is branching and quite interesting, the happenings on the way have mostly more then one way to complete them. Furthermore there are different factions you encounter and can ally with them and in general the way you behave throughout the game affects every location/faction. Last but not least you also have the possibility to get your own stronghold, which is to be restored as well as cared about.. and even has an own multiple level dungeon. Personally i would have wished for some more class specific dialogue options (especially the cipher class), but that´s a minor complain.
Your companions are well made and have their own personalities as well as quests, though could use some more banter.

On a further note regarding Obsidian and their reputation for delivering bug plagued games, i think the self management through Kickstarter helped them, as i had few problems in that regard. Also the game keeps getting improved after release.
The downside of the Kickstarter, if you want to call it one, are many KS characters, who stand around throughout towns mostly and some little sh*tstorm made once more by some extremists who were to dumb and fanatic to understand irony.

Conclusio: If you are a fan of (old) isometric, group related rpgs on an epic scale then you can´t do anything wrong with this game.

Read More

Shannon Green
188 products in account
4 reviews
Recommended
585.9 hrs on record
Posted: June 3
'Pillars of Eternity is a role-playing game that features a party-based real-time-with-pause tactical gameplay, fixed isometric user interface for the game-world with two-dimensional pre-rendered backdrops, in a similar vein as its spiritual predecessors Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale series and Planescape: Torment.' - Wikipedia

The games' well written lore is a jewel among other jewels but definitely the diamond. If you read it and adjust to the screenplay, you'll know a revolutionary story with some characters you'll seldom forget. The story is full of serene optimism that you can terrorize or support, and a twisted dark, that makes the perfect enemy, or friend.

The graphics of characters are sharp and fluid; your party shimmers in the high-resolution environment, especially during battles with all the special effects from talents. The on-screen visuals and the in-mind visuals about this game are of the highest quality for the format.

Gameplay consists of issuing commands and then watching your party act, moving by pointing and clicking, and by either clicking on the icon of your talents or using set hotkeys, you attack or use defensive and healing abilities. Positioning and map control are definitely elements of Path of the Damned ( hardest difficulty ) mode.

Nerd House
2,248 products in account
150 reviews
Recommended
44.5 hrs on record
Posted: August 30
Pillars of Eternity
Developer : Obsidian Entertainment
Publisher : Paradox Interactive

Note: I will try to be as spoiler-free as possible.
Note #2: I don't think I can do this game justice, but I'll try anyway.

Introduction
==========
Quite possibly the best isometric CRPG to be released in recent years, Pillars of Eternity is an entirely new world expertly crafted and filled with lore created in the style of the classic Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale games. Any fan of these games will instantly fall in love with Pillars of Eternity and it's similar design.

Gameplay
==========
Played from an isometric top-down view, Pillars is packed with things to do. You play the game entirely by mouse, pointing and clicking to navigate each area, converse with NPCs, battle enemies, and more. One of the best things about this game is that it is extremely detailed and immersive with it's superb storytelling. Pretty much exactly like the titles mentioned above. There is a literal TON of reading, as everything is presented to you in much the same way a dungeonmaster or storyteller in a tabletop game would. Every detail is spelled out for you, and you get to make you own choices in each dialogue. Most of these choices have a profound impact on the outcome of whatever quest you are on (people can and will die!), and even the main storyline.

You start out by creating a character from a huge list of options. There are a small handful of races, several classes, and you can even choose some regional differences for each race. You could easily spend and hour or more creating your first character. Along with your "main" character, there are 8 (10 with The White March Part I add-on) unique companions you can recruit. You can also create more characters to join your party after a certain point. Each character can be customized the way you see fit from an extensive list of spells, abilities, auras, talents, and equipment.

One of the big features of Pillars is the Stronghold. Shortly into the game you come into ownership of a stronghold called Caed Nua. Caed Nua, once owned, can be upgraded and repaired to offer you a variety of new features, goods, and services. For example, you can build an Inn that will allow you to rest. Another example is you can construct a barracks which unlocks the character creator. Also found underneath Caed Nua is an extensive maze-like dungeon, which can be explored throughout the game, with each floor getting more difficult.

There are many options in battle, and probably the most helpful (but sometimes annoying) of which is the Auto-Pause feature. This can be set to activate when any number of events occur, such as a character's Endurance dropping too low. Pausing allows you to survey the battlefield and make the best decision possible to turn the tide back into your favor.

An important part of any RPG is inventory management. With a game of this scope, there are naturally a ton of different items: weapons, armor, accessories, food, potions, scrolls, crafting ingredients, and more. With all of these items, you need a way to store and manage everything. Thankfully, each character has their own inventory, and you can freely move items between them at anytime. But the biggest boon to item management is the Stash. On your inventory screen, you will see a large button with a Treasure Chest on it. This is your Stash, which can be accessed from nearly anywhere, at anytime, and is seemingly infinite in capacity. If it has a limit, I never found it!

Most RPGs are packed full of quests and tasks, and with this comes th eneed to manage them. The quest log in Pillars is pretty detailed, giving a sort of summary of any actions taken during a quest. This is extremely helpful, in that if you take a break from the game you can easily come back and jump right back to what you left off on. This is a common complaint of some of the larger RPGs, that when picking the game back up after awhile players have no idea what they were last doing, so they start over. Pillars eliminates that problem entirely.

When you reach the edge of a map, you are able to leave the area and return to the World Map. From here, you can travel to any previously visited location no matter how far across the map it is. This fast travel is extremely helpful in navigating the world and completing objectives.

Graphics
==========
If you liked the graphics of Baldur's Gate, then you'll love the updated style Pillars of Eternity offers. You can zoom in and out at anytime, and the closer you zoom in, the more detail you will see on nearly everything. The characters in particular are very well done, as are the environments and maps of each area. They all look superb.

I simply cannot say enough about how good this game looks. All of it is very well-made and designed, and really draws your eye to the details. It's just so detailed and beautiful as a result. The only downside is that there isn't too much variety. The entire base game map is mostly woodlands and forests, and all of the dungeons look really similar...stone and darkness. It isn't until you get the White March Part 1 add-on that you start to see more varied environments (SNOW!).

Sound and Music
==========
Absolutely amazing. The soundtrack is wonderfully immersive, and extremely well-done. Making the soundtrack available in the store was a great move. Once I'm able to afford the Champion Edition upgrade, I'll definitely get it JUST for the soundtrack alone. I'm a huge fan of video game music anyway. I found no problems with any of it. Every track was expertly paired with the right situations in-game for full immersion.

The sound effects are extremely well done too, even footsteps. This is a game I play with my sound up full blast, there's a lot of details in each area that's conveyed via the sound. Each area has a lot of ambient effects, like crickets in a woodland setting or stones shifting as you traverse a dungeon.

Performance
==========
This game ran flawlessly on my low mid-tier rig. No hiccups whatsosver. No framerate drops, lag, stuttering, or random crashes. The framerate did appear to be capped at 30 though, as I never saw it go over that. I'll need to pay attention next time I play and make a note about it.

One of the main complaints (well, only complaint) I have with this game is that inbetween every single area you will run into a loading screen that takes anywhere from 5-15 seconds to clear off. Thankfully, these screens feature some beautiful artwork and often helpful tips about the game, so it's not too big of an issue.

Final Thoughts
==========
Pillars of Eternity is a MUST PLAY for fans of the CRPG genre. A truly immersive and expansive adventure that you can play your way. If you enjoyed any of the games mentioned at the top of this review, you *need* to have this game in your library. And with the recently released White March Part 1 add-on and accompanying patch that added some much needed features to the game (Party AI), it's gotten even better! Don't pass this up, it's well worth the price of admission.

A Must Play

raphaelsetz
139 products in account
1 review
Not Recommended
60.5 hrs on record
Posted: May 16
I just finished my first playthrough on the hard difficulty and on expert mode.
I don't give this game a "thumbs down" because it is a bad game, but because of the wasted potential, the half-♥♥♥♥♥ gameplay concepts and the fact that it's predecessors (Baldur's Gate and the likes) have done so much more so much better. Here I'll post a few examples to prove my point. Pretty much all of my criticism concerns features that are much better thought through and implemented properly in BG/IWD - so there should be no opportunity to make such a list:

Classes:
- the thief has no benefits at all in regards of sneaking, unlocking stuff and disarming traps compared to any other class?!
- no pickpocketing
- you can only place one trap in total, which makes the underwhelming traps even more useless
- chanters are boring to play. You can only use their special power once, somethimes twice in a fight
- choosing solely defensive abilities on a fighters makes him pretty much invulnerable (on hard difficulty my tank never got in any trouble although he always drew aggro from the majority of enemies)
- due to the lack of special abilities and ammunition the ranger is boring to play and the companion (I only tested the wolf) is downright useless and gets knocked out every fight
- a paladin with no anti-undead abilities?!

Inventory/items:
- I don't get why you would implement the stash the way the developers did. It totally eradicates inventory management and you get to collect and sell all the loot you come across. The entire game I had more money than I could spend, even purchasing the useless upgrades for my castle. Does my party drag a 10 ton freight container around all the time or how the heck does this work.
- why does a food vendor buy 200 weapons and armors from me?
- no need to identify found items. Do they all come with instruction manuals and product descriptions?
- the inventory of vendors never changes and the majority don't sell anything that could be considered a remarkable upgrade (oh the times when you crawled out of Irenicus' dungeon and stumbled into Adventurer's Mart)

Combat mechanics:
- you have no possibility of preparation for a battle whatsoever. This not only reduces tactics to a nostalgic wish, it also makes combat unnecessarily boring. Therefore scouting out enemies is useless and, thanks to the broken stealth mechanic, not possible at all most of the time
- You can't drink certain potions, use certain abilities or spells while not in combat. What?! Why?
- I got bitten by a spider as large as a house and got poisoned. Yet there are no anti-venom potions or spells and after killing the beast a few seconds later, the poison was gone and the character rehealed instantly back to full endurance. This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and would make being prepared for such situations needless, even if it were possible
- no ammunition for ranged weapons. This would've been soo easy to implement and boost the tactical aspect of combat a lot!
- not a single battle where I had to stack e.g. all the fire defense I can get to survive

Magic:
- the spell system is a joke compared to it's predecessors
- the available buffs are so weak, short timed and limited, they're not worth the time clicking through the unergonomic menus to cast (some buffs only last 3 seconds - are you kidding me, it uses more time to cast)
- the range on AoE spells is a joke, why can't I cover the screen in exploding fireballs and clouds of deathly gas?
- the game can't decide if it wants to use friendly fire or not, some spells affect companions, some don't, why not just provide the option to toggle all friendly fire on or off

Experience system:
- why do NPCs have the same exp when I meet them regardless whether I am level 1 or 12?! Do they live in a magical training dimension?
- I don't like how every character has the exact same exp levels independent of his class and everyone levels up at the same instant
- I like how I only get exp from killing enemies until I've finished my bestiary. But why doesn't this provide me with a combat bonus against these enemies?

Crafting:
- crafting doesn't make sense at all. Why can I do it anywhere and anytime? At least make me carry a mortar and pestle or limit it to doing it when resting
- why does mixing a few herbs to create a potion cost hundreds of copper? Do my characters just throw the money on the ground to calm the gods of potion mixing??
- why is the minimum 2 potions, costing 2 of every ingredient?

A lot more:
- no boss fights that would be worthy of that name
- no epic loot that would make a difference, just combinations of the same boring properties I can craft myself
- no thinking challenges or riddles
- no random events like ambushes when traveling or attacks while resting in a dungeon
- no humor or funny/silly side stories or quests that would lighten up the continuously dark and gritty atmosphere
- no deceptions, at least none that I can recall. Everyone in this world seems to be honest, no one tries to trick you
- the castle is, apart from the dungeon below which could be anywhere else, useless and doesn't provide any benefit to the game
- companions don't have an alignment, so nobody cares much whether you do good or bad

To conclude this 'review' (it's more of a rant, I know) I have to admit that I liked the game just as much to make me finish the main story and invest 60 hours into it. Sadly there's not much else out there recently in this genre. Maybe this will provide some input to build upon in the sequel.

Vlodril
249 products in account
28 reviews
Recommended
97.9 hrs on record
Posted: May 11
Pillars of Eternity is Obsidian's first try to make a game without any publisher pushing (which is what fans believed was always the problem with the bugs in their games for example) thansk to their kickstarter campaign.

As it turns out yes they can release a well polished game (even with a huge complicated world like poe).

Managed to finish the game after 75 hours more or less so you can see this is a huge game.

there is tons of quests both main and sidequests and most of them are actually decent (not the go there and get me 5 furs kind). Even in the few "fetch" quests there is a story there and twists that made them fresh and enjoyable.

The game looks very pretty if you like the old school isometric style, has a great soundtrack which managed not to bore me after playing the game for 70+ hours.

Everyone who likes the genre this is perhaps the top crpg that has come out in the last 10+ years and certainly the best kickstarted project i have backed so far (although shadowrun is a close second).

There is a ton of options in the dialogues and choices that can and will affect the world in quite a big way (unlike other "rpgs" which will not be named).

The combat was interesting and engaging and quite hard even on normal especially on the start of the game.

There is also a huge totally optional dungeon in game (14-15 floors).

Definitely recommend this game and i hope obsidian can go back to ks and would gladly back them for more.
